intro: Allardia lasiocarpa, commonly known as the hairy fruit allardia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed capsule that is covered in fine hairs, giving it the specific epithet "lasiocarpa," meaning "hairy fruit." Allardia lasiocarpa is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes.
